body:

##### Comment last updated on October 12, 2018 at 16:26 Hours UTC

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23062?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [cf11f71...d097b43](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23062?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

@WillAyd 
I did it right here (where it belongs IMO). Not sure I got everything, because there are some Win32 errors in the plotting tests that were already there before.

i don’t think any real urgency to bump numexpr or bottleneck mins

we generally try to allow packages to continue to work as much as possible

> i don’t think any real urgency to bump numexpr or bottleneck mins
we generally try to allow packages to continue to work as much as possible

I only bumped them because anything lower is not compatible with numpy>=1.12 (you can check the respective builds to see that always something was failing due to unresolvable dependencies)
In core.ops there is a try/except for `np.broadcast_to` that can be simplified along with this PR.

Clearly the sane option would have been not to touch the mpl compat code...

In any case, I investigated the conda resolvability things, and locally, I get:
```
(pandas-dev) C:\[...]\pddev>conda install "numpy>=1.12" "bottleneck<1.2.0"
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - bottleneck[version='<1.2.0'] -> numpy=1.10
  - numpy[version='>=1.12']

(pandas-dev) C:\[...]\pddev>conda install "numpy>=1.12" "matplotlib<2.0.0"
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - matplotlib[version='<2.0.0'] -> numpy=1.6
  - numpy[version='>=1.12']
  
(pandas-dev) C:\[...]\pddev>conda install "numpy>=1.12" "pytables<3.2.2"
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - numpy[version='>=1.12']
  - pytables[version='<3.2.2'] -> numexpr=2.0 -> numpy=1.6

(pandas-dev) C:\[...]\pddev>conda install "numpy>=1.12" "scipy<0.18.1"
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - numpy[version='>=1.12']
  - scipy[version='<0.18.1'] -> numpy=1.6
```

That's why reduced the version bump for `pytables`, but now https://circleci.com/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/24379
says:
```
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - numpy=1.12.0
  - pytables=3.2.2 -> numexpr=2.5 -> numpy=1.10
```

Not sure where this is coming from, but going back up to `3.4.2`.

OK, https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23062/commits/b971bfba245efde575269eca38b09a614256e33b is finally green for all MPL versions. Removing the debugging stuff and reverting most of the pins (I left two to also test `2.0.1` and `2.2.2`, which would be untested otherwise).
lgtm. can you rebase. @TomAugspurger ok with the plotting cleanups? should merge this before SparseArray? (to avoid some hacks for backward compat)?
Plotting changes look fine. No need to merge before / after sparse array. The hacks there are minimal, and I think will be addressed in time anyway.

@TomAugspurger 
There's something wrong with the azure failure reporting (discovered by accident):
The last three runs reported success despite two failures in the Mac job:
https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=961
https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=964
https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=1045

> There's something wrong with the azure failure reporting (discovered by accident):
The last three runs reported success despite two failures in the Mac job

I've been troubleshooting the same problem [here](https://github.com/jbrockmendel/sm2/pull/96), please let me know if you figure it out

I understand now why no-one touched the matplotlib compat for a long time (e.g. `_mpl_le_1_2_1` still around, while the lowest tested version prior to this PR was 1.4.3)...

In any case, I've now got a passing CI on all mpl builds again in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23062/commits/079bdaf078733adc1faa1d076a43f8b86ea9a44c (after the false positive from azure; there are no pins or changed code paths for matplotlib in Circle, which is lagging behind due to not cancelling on new pushes):
`2.0.0`, `2.0.1`, `2.1.0`, `2.2.0`, `2.2.2`, `2.2.3`, `3.0.0`

Reverting the pins, then this thing should be done...

@TomAugspurger @jreback another quick look?

pls rebase

not you will have to rebase somewhat frequently until this is merged

> note you will have to rebase somewhat frequently until this is merged

What's the hold-up on getting this merged soon?
PS. Can someone trigger the circleCI runs? not sure why they didn't start.
this. needs review for the plotting changes
I don't see any way to trigger a circle build from their UI. Probably easiest to add an empty commit.
lgtm. @WillAyd if ok, pls accept, but after that @h-vetinari will need a rebase then, just before merging to make sure nothing has changed. (you can rebase now if you want).
Not much happened in the last 17h (3 commits), but ok.
thanks @h-vetinari

This was quite the effort I have to say. MPL has some really weird behaviour in that (e.g.) several times in `test_datetimelike` there's:
* behaviour A in `2.0.0`, `2.2.0` and `3.0.0`
* behaviour B in `2.0.1`, `2.1.0`, `2.2.2`, `2.2.3`.

Not 100% sure this is not overlaid with some numpy/system dependencies as well, but happy that right now everything passes and got merged.
